\begin{definition}[Sample Space]
The \textbf{sample space} $\Omega$ is the set of all possible outcomes of an experiment. Each element $\omega \in \Omega$ is called a \textbf{sample point} or \textbf{outcome}.
\end{definition}

\bigskip

\begin{definition}[Probability Law]
A \textbf{probability law} is a function $P$ that assigns to every event $A \subseteq \Omega$ a nonnegative number $P(A)$ satisfying:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item \textbf{Nonnegativity:} $P(A) \geq 0$ for all $A$
  \item \textbf{Additivity:} If $A \cap B = \emptyset$, then $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B)$
  \item \textbf{Normalization:} $P(\Omega) = 1$
\end{enumerate}
\end{definition}
